awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EARS: Large-Scale Statistical Learning based Spectrum Sensing and Cognitive Networking
awd_abstract_narration: As cognitive radio (CR) research advances to multihop and complex systems over large geographic regions, the spectrum utilization enhancement should be generalized to fully exploit the spectrum usage diversity in three dimensions  (3D): time, frequency, and space, with new emphasis on the under-explored spatial dimension. Accordingly, this project focuses on the following three research objectives. The first one is to utilize the recent advancements in statistical learning over big data to develop efficient 3D spectrum sensing schemes, where a hierarchical approach is taken in developing novel finite-bit and single-bit learning techniques to efficiently explore the correlation structure across the three dimensions, with an advanced distributed approach also developed. The second one is to develop two key building blocks in large-scale CR networking based on the 3D spectrum sensing: 1) a novel multi-scale routing scheme to enhance the overall spectrum utilization, with a focus on exploiting the layered spectrum usage correlation structure in the spatial dimension; and 2) a reliable hierarchical common control channel identification scheme. The last research objective is to validate some key aspects in the proposed sensing and networking schemes via both intensive simulations and a concept-proving testbed. Throughout the project, an interdisciplinary approach is taken to combine the methods of statistical learning, signal processing, and wireless networking, with the core built upon the hierarchical treatment of both spectrum usage statistics and CR networking methodologies. The project provides both theories and algorithms for large-scale spectrum sensing and cognitive networking. Through a coherent education plan, the research findings will be incorporated into courses, and disseminated to the community via journal papers and conference presentations.

por.por_cntn:
Exploiting spectrum correlation enables a cognitive radio network (CRN) to achieve higher spectrum utilization and better networking performance. Since most existing CRN research is focused on small networks, the exploitation of spectrum correlation has been mainly restricted to the time and frequency domains within a small spatial neighborhood. As CRN research advances to multihop and complex systems over large geographic regions, the spectrum utilization should be generalized to fully account for the correlations in three dimensions (3D): time, frequency, and space, with new emphasis on the under-explored spatial dimension. Taking advantage of the recent advancements in statistical learning over big data, this project focuses on the statistical modeling of spectrum correlation in the space, time, and frequency domains, and on utilizing the 3D spectrum correlation for efficient large-scale CRN protocol design and optimization.

The main intellectual merit outcome of this project includes:

1. Based on real channel measurement data, several machine-learning models have been developed to characterize spectrum correlations in the space, time, and frequency domains. Several theoretical models have also been proposed to characterize the spatial channel correlation in the indoor and outdoor environments, respectively.

2. Exploiting the 3D spectrum correlation, a new inference attack model has been proposed to compromise the physical (PHY) layer security of wireless networks. We have shown that the 3D spectrum correlation enables an attacker to statistically infer the current link signature of a target channel by observing several nearby channels, or by observing the past link signatures of the target channel, and hence renders many PHY-layer security mechanisms, such as a link-signature-based secret key extraction scheme, at a high risk of being compromised. In light of such inference attacks, a novel multilink forward-backward cooperative key generation protocol has been proposed as a countermeasure.  

3. A new type of optimal stopping model, which maximizes a desired percentile of the rate of return at stopping time, is studied to address the Quality-of-Service (QoS) compliant optimal sequential channel sensing problem for cognitive radios (CRs). This new model enables a resource-constrained CR that does not have prior knowledge of the spectrum to maximize its min-rate throughput under a desired spectrum access delay constraint by sequentially sensing and accessing channels in the spectrum.

4. A stable matching solution has been studied to address the cognitive context-aware distributed storage problem in mobile cloud computing. Being a fully distributed algorithm, the proposed solution minimizes mobile users’ data access delay while keeping the network resource consumption at its minimum. The proposed optimization takes into account an array of fine-grained user context information, including spectrum sensing outcome, users’ mobility pattern, network condition, and data access pattern.

5. A novel routing mechanism has been proposed to perform geographic routing in context-aware wireless networks without leaking the location privacy of the route. Employing a Hilbert Curve for space encryption, the proposed solution achieves its privacy goal by enabling one to compute efficient geographic routes directly based on the ciphertext of locations.

The broader impact outcomes of this project include:

1. This project has generated new knowledge on the 3D modeling of spectrum correlation and the utilization of such correlation in CRN design and optimization. In addition, this project is interdisciplinary and draws methods from machine learning, optimization, signal processing, networking, wireless communication, and cyber security. This research enriches all these disciplines.

2. The research outcome has been disseminated to the wireless community via publications, talks, and posters. Some of the research results have been integrated into the course materials taught by the PI at the undergraduate and graduate levels. This project has also been introduced to many high-school students in Metro Detroit area at Engineering Days of the Oakland University and at E-days of the Auburn University. This helps to foster the high-school students' interests in taking science and technology as their future career.

3. This project has supported several Ph.D. students, including two female students. Through this project, they have received rigid training in programming, statistics and random process, optimization, wireless networking, machine learning, and cyber security. In addition, they also acquired hands-on experience in the simulation and testbed development. The above training and hands-on experience will lay a solid foundation for their future career development.
